componenttext: Our next question or comment is from Ryan Tunis from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones, I think. Hopefully, quick ones on the property business with ARX. I would say, during the quarter, net written premiums grew a little more than we would have expected. I'm wondering if there's any portion of that, that we can
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones, I think. Hopefully, quick ones on the property business with ARX. I would say, during the quarter, net written premiums grew a little more than we would have expected. I'm wondering if there's any portion of that, that we can attribute to higher retention or different reinsurance buying or anything along those lines?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Why don't we try to give you a little bit of insight to those numbers. I know they're confusing in some parts. There'll be some changes in the way we address direct written premium with the reinsurance accounting and so on and so forth. Bottom line is
componenttext: No. Why don't we try to give you a little bit of insight to those numbers. I know they're confusing in some parts. There'll be some changes in the way we address direct written premium with the reinsurance accounting and so on and so forth. Bottom line is, ARX's first quarter and second quarter were not dramatically different. While we didn't have ownership at the levels we have and consolidated reporting. So we haven't given you that, but if you really want to look, you can find the statutory numbers out there. And I tell you, the second quarter is roughly the same as the first, but nothing in this league of dramatic that is worth reporting or a dramatic change in retention. Frankly, in the 90 days, while we're extremely happy with everything that's going on, there's nothing dramatic to report.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, just on the expense ratio x the -- sorry.
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, just on the expense ratio x the -- sorry.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just reiterate what Glenn said, we are changing the way we account for our reinsurance obligations that take place normally around June and December each year. So that net written premium may not be wholly indicative of the growth rate. The direct
componenttext: I would just reiterate what Glenn said, we are changing the way we account for our reinsurance obligations that take place normally around June and December each year. So that net written premium may not be wholly indicative of the growth rate. The direct written premium will be much more indicative of the actual growth rate. So I would focus on that number. We can't obviously report prior year because we didn't have the ownership stake. So we can't give you apples-to-apples right now. Their second quarter statutory data will come out fairly soon, and you'll be able to see the direct written premium growth in those statements. I'll also add though that while growth in homeowners is great, the more important growth is growth in bundles. So that was the intent of the transaction and come together far more closely than we previously did. And that's where we're going to get the biggest benefit. So if we could overnight bundle the entire ARX book with auto, we'd be way happier than growing the homeowner piece. So just want to reiterate that's the intent of what we're trying to do there.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And closely coupled with that, when we talk bundle, you should think policy life expectancy and amortization of fixed expenses and the like and improvement typically in loss costs. So those are the things that really are as I think I wrote once before the
componenttext: And closely coupled with that, when we talk bundle, you should think policy life expectancy and amortization of fixed expenses and the like and improvement typically in loss costs. So those are the things that really are as I think I wrote once before the currency of this transaction.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. And I guess just on the expense ratio. Again, trying to reconcile that in ARX to some of the stat data we see. I think x amortization costs, sort of low 30s. I mean, is that a good run rate to use going forward or is there anything we
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. And I guess just on the expense ratio. Again, trying to reconcile that in ARX to some of the stat data we see. I think x amortization costs, sort of low 30s. I mean, is that a good run rate to use going forward or is there anything we should be thinking about there in terms of a jump up in expenses, or anything in the like?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd make 2 comments on that. We do have Trevor Hillier, the CFO of ASI here with us. But first I want to clarify a comment I made earlier in the call talking about our expense ratio being down 0.5 point. That is on the vehicle side or personal line side.
componenttext: I'd make 2 comments on that. We do have Trevor Hillier, the CFO of ASI here with us. But first I want to clarify a comment I made earlier in the call talking about our expense ratio being down 0.5 point. That is on the vehicle side or personal line side. You add in the ARX expense ratio and look at our total, we're flatter. But the ASI expense ratio net of amortization expenses is more in the low 20s. So I think 24-ish. You can correct me if I'm wrong on that, Trevor.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that's correct. It's between 23% and 24%. We've held that for a few periods. I think one thing you mentioned was comparing our statutory numbers with the numbers reported in the Progressive numbers. Is that correct?
componenttext: No, that's correct. It's between 23% and 24%. We've held that for a few periods. I think one thing you mentioned was comparing our statutory numbers with the numbers reported in the Progressive numbers. Is that correct?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I did. Yes.
componenttext: I did. Yes.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: The difference there is mainly with our consolidated group that's reported with Progressive includes our managing general agents, which is not included in the statutory results. The statutory results are just insurance companies. So it won't reconcile one
componenttext: The difference there is mainly with our consolidated group that's reported with Progressive includes our managing general agents, which is not included in the statutory results. The statutory results are just insurance companies. So it won't reconcile one to one.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question or comment is from Todd Bault from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question or comment is from Todd Bault from Citi.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a variant question on something you raised earlier about high growth rates could change mix. For what it's worth, our research has shown that over the last few years, you've done a pretty good job of your pricing and loss trends tracking e
componenttext: I wanted to ask a variant question on something you raised earlier about high growth rates could change mix. For what it's worth, our research has shown that over the last few years, you've done a pretty good job of your pricing and loss trends tracking each other, within a couple of points, of course. Who knows if that's correct. But knowing what you know about your pricing and monitoring systems, if you went for a period where your pricing was more or less tracking your loss trends, would that have an ancillary effect of maintaining your portfolio homogeneity? In other words, your risks would be more or less as you expected. Or are those quite independent? In other words, could your account pricing track loss trend well, but you could still have pretty large shifts in homogeneity? And that's all I have.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think if we -- and our intent is to always have pricing track out losses. And to the extent that a new inflow of business changes the homogeneity of the book in place, it's always easier to manage a static book. It's not much fun, but it's easier. T
componenttext: No. I think if we -- and our intent is to always have pricing track out losses. And to the extent that a new inflow of business changes the homogeneity of the book in place, it's always easier to manage a static book. It's not much fun, but it's easier. The real question is, is the new incoming mix equivalent to, similar to, different than what you currently have? And we don't expect that to necessarily be the case. In fact, and this is conjecture, so not a statement of fact, everything we are doing and seeing and have reported several of the trends today, Snapshot usage, how that's trending to multiproduct customers, the notion of Platinum. We have every reason to believe the mix of business coming in may be more preferred overall than what we've seen before. So that would be a positive. And then your pricing, unlikely to have any great effect, but should be positive to the loss costs.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question or comment is from Al Copersino from Columbia Management.
componenttext: Our next question or comment is from Al Copersino from Columbia Management.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to a couple of earlier questions just because I personally was a bit confused and that's probably my own fault. In response to questions from Ian, you all spoke about the importance of looking at the overall calendar year combined rati
componenttext: I wanted to go back to a couple of earlier questions just because I personally was a bit confused and that's probably my own fault. In response to questions from Ian, you all spoke about the importance of looking at the overall calendar year combined ratio. In response to questions from Meyer, I believe you said that your focus is on the accident year, more so than the calendar year. And so number one, I want to make sure I understood that right. Maybe there were 2 separate issues being discussed. And then the secondarily and part of that was, it does appear as Ian was saying that the reserve releases remain strong, but the underlying loss ratio continues to be higher. I don't know if that should be cause for concern or if that should be cause for future optimism that the -- that those 2 -- that the reserve releases may, in fact, be a leading indicator of an eventual improvement in the underlying loss ratio. So I wonder if you could respond to those 2 issues.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll try, I don't remember the specific reference to calendar, but that maybe me. Let me just sort of suggest to you, as far as I'm concerned, we think in terms of accident year, most of the time. Calendar year is just sort of an adjustment for the q
componenttext: Yes. I'll try, I don't remember the specific reference to calendar, but that maybe me. Let me just sort of suggest to you, as far as I'm concerned, we think in terms of accident year, most of the time. Calendar year is just sort of an adjustment for the quality defects in reserving in a previous way -- in a previous period. So accident year for me is almost exclusively the way we like to look at the business. Clearly, we all understand that those adjustments are made from an accounting perspective, but accident year is probably a better way to look at the economics versus the accounting. I thought I tried to get at this with Ian's question, maybe I wasn't clear. Degradation in the loss ratio under certain circumstances might be a really bad situation. If on the other hand, the loss ratio was lower than your previously designed target, then it might be perfectly acceptable to move towards your target. Clearly, not acceptable to go beyond your target. If and when market conditions are such that you're willing to give up 1 point of loss ratio and get what you considered to be proportionate volume or the elasticity of the market is willing to give it to you, then those are trade-offs that not only do we make, it's sort of the heart and soul of what we say is the guiding principles of Progressive. And that is, we attempt to make a 4% underwriting profit. If and when we do, we try to grow as fast as possible. And it's very much that sequence and we are quite comfortable right now seeing that the market will give us some growth, and we want to be priced as close to our target as we can. So hopefully, that clarifies it. But I think accident year is by far more of the economics of the company, the calendar year is the accounting.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Josh Shanker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate always all the tools you give us to analyze things. And I asked this question on the Allstate conference call, but not sure that I'm any smarter. Can you tell me the difference between paid frequency trends and incurred frequency trends? And
componenttext: I appreciate always all the tools you give us to analyze things. And I asked this question on the Allstate conference call, but not sure that I'm any smarter. Can you tell me the difference between paid frequency trends and incurred frequency trends? And to the extent, is incurred frequency generally a more leading indicator?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm actually going to probably ask Gary to determine that. I will tell you that from my perspective, I spend most of my time on incurred. Paid may or may not be an indicator, not necessarily one way or another, sort of which way ultimately your prior tren
componenttext: I'm actually going to probably ask Gary to determine that. I will tell you that from my perspective, I spend most of my time on incurred. Paid may or may not be an indicator, not necessarily one way or another, sort of which way ultimately your prior trend picks might be adjusted. But Gary spends more of his time on this. If I were you, I will focus more on incurred frequency.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, is Gary Traicoff, Chief Actuary. I think just to add to Glenn's point. We look at both, but I typically rely more on the incurred frequency as opposed to paid. A couple of the issues you could have with paid frequency is when you have changes in clos
componenttext: Yes, is Gary Traicoff, Chief Actuary. I think just to add to Glenn's point. We look at both, but I typically rely more on the incurred frequency as opposed to paid. A couple of the issues you could have with paid frequency is when you have changes in closure rate, for example. That could distort what your paid frequency looks like, whereas the incurred frequency should be a lot more stable.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And when you spoke about July frequency being up, is that a spike relative to July 2014 or relative to June 2015?
componenttext: And when you spoke about July frequency being up, is that a spike relative to July 2014 or relative to June 2015?

componenttextpreview: I think we should clarify the earlier comments. Glenn said vehicle miles traveled are up in July. He didn't say frequency was up in July.
componenttext: I think we should clarify the earlier comments. Glenn said vehicle miles traveled are up in July. He didn't say frequency was up in July.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good point. Good point.
componenttext: Good point. Good point.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And also he commented that the mix of types of trips has changed. So I think of it as, as gas prices have gotten more competitive, more people are taking vacations instead of staycations this summer. So we did not say that frequency is up in July, miles t
componenttext: And also he commented that the mix of types of trips has changed. So I think of it as, as gas prices have gotten more competitive, more people are taking vacations instead of staycations this summer. So we did not say that frequency is up in July, miles traveled is up and up more than it's been. I think we showed you back in May it's been up for a number of months now and July took a little further tick up.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from [indiscernible] from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our last question comes from [indiscernible] from Sterne Agee.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up on one thing was the accident year combined ratio x cats on the personal lines business. So the first quarter year-over-year, I mean, my numbers show that the accident year combined was up around 2.9 points. Second quarter, that s
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on one thing was the accident year combined ratio x cats on the personal lines business. So the first quarter year-over-year, I mean, my numbers show that the accident year combined was up around 2.9 points. Second quarter, that slows down to plus 0.6 points. So curious as to what's happening there, why is the rate of deterioration slowing? I mean, have you been taking pricing up or have loss cost trends slowed recently?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: John?
componenttext: John?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: The expense ratio, so the loss ratio would be the driver of those. So I'd go back to Glenn's answer on that issue. We are always pricing the business to -- and I would add, maybe a little confusion to what he had said actually and say, when we price busin
componenttext: The expense ratio, so the loss ratio would be the driver of those. So I'd go back to Glenn's answer on that issue. We are always pricing the business to -- and I would add, maybe a little confusion to what he had said actually and say, when we price business, we're pricing the lifetime combined ratios. So there are instances where we are growing segments faster or slower and the new business is always going to be a different combined ratio than the renewal business and the mix of that business can drive calendar effects. We are pricing to the lifetime combined ratio by segment, but we are also managing the company to that 96% or better calendar year constantly. So there's a couple different objective functions we are meeting there. And I think, again, we're really comfortable with our pricing across all business lines. And we think we are doing exactly what Glenn said, which is meeting or beating that 96%, and we want to get grow as fast as we can.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd also encourage you to think about at least in the case of Progressive as pricing is more of a continuous variable than a discrete variable that happens every so often. We give you in the Q the average premium, the rate of increase of average premium.
componenttext: I'd also encourage you to think about at least in the case of Progressive as pricing is more of a continuous variable than a discrete variable that happens every so often. We give you in the Q the average premium, the rate of increase of average premium. You can see that's reasonably healthy, which is also going to affect the loss ratio as long as that average premium is going up faster than the rate of increase in the pure premium. So just factor all those things in, there are a lot of moving parts. This is more a informational comment. One of the things that we do is we track all rate revisions done on a monthly basis. That's usually for us that we track about 200 to 400 rate revisions. So think 50 states, many carriers. We're seeing, on average, and as I cluster the last data points, it's quite a variable function. If I cluster the last data points, I'm seeing a market rate of increase at about 2.6% give or take. And there's a give or take to that. And we gave you an average premium increase of 4% in our personal lines business. So we're at least sort of keeping up with that or perhaps our pricing got ahead of that and others are now perhaps catching up. We also have some mechanisms in our rates in many states where we're actually continuously taking just a little bit. It doesn't account for a great deal, but it means that each time, we can soften the discrete event of having to adjust for rates. So don't be surprised that you'll see over time a little bit of closure, even in the situation that you're recognizing other than our pricing targets, which is the biggest one, but you will see premiums change at a slightly different rate than pure premiums and in some part, that's by design.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 06, 2015

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference call is also available via an audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any
componenttext:
Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference call is also available via an audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
The company will not make detailed comments in addition to those provided in its quarterly report on Form 10-Q and letter to shareholders, which had been posted to the company's website and will use this conference call to respond to questions. Acting as moderator for the call will be Julia Hornack. At this time, I will turn the call over to Ms. Hornack.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; John Sauerland, our CFO; and Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. The call is scheduled to last about an hour.As always, our discussion
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; John Sauerland, our CFO; and Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. The call is scheduled to last about an hour.
As always, our discussions on this call may include forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to many risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events and results to differ materially from those discussed during this call. Additional information concerning those risks and uncertainties is available in our 2014 annual report on Form 10-K and our first quarter 2015 quarterly report on Form 10-Q, where you will find discussions of the risk factors affecting our businesses, safe harbor statements relating to forward-looking statements and other discussions of the risks, uncertainties and other challenges we face. These documents can be found via the Investors page of our website, progressive.com. 
Corey, we are now ready to take our first question.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Vinay Misquith from Sterne Agee Center.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Vinay Misquith from Sterne Agee Center.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the hot topic of discussion, I guess, is frequency. So I'd be curious to hear from you, what changed this quarter? Was it the past for the higher frequency? Was it individual states? And what do you think is going to well happen for the future?
componenttext: So the hot topic of discussion, I guess, is frequency. So I'd be curious to hear from you, what changed this quarter? Was it the past for the higher frequency? Was it individual states? And what do you think is going to well happen for the future?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I don't understand why there'll be a topic. So let's try to give us much color as possible, tell me if I'm being responsive to your questions. If I look at frequency, the one thing I would tell you, at least I would encourage you, look at time
componenttext: Yes, sure. I don't understand why there'll be a topic. So let's try to give us much color as possible, tell me if I'm being responsive to your questions. If I look at frequency, the one thing I would tell you, at least I would encourage you, look at time sequence of frequency because individual data points can be sort of interesting, but all over the map. So if we look at through the second quarter, we were right in line with the industry. And so nothing particularly notable there on frequency. And we did have, and I'm sure it's been a story, obviously a couple of companies, big companies, very credible companies reported frequency that was considerably higher than the industry. This quarter, we're reporting frequency up and not dramatically so. So I will break that down a little bit and try to give you how with -- or our thinking around that is. So BMI PD are sort of in the 4 range. And frankly, from my perspective, if you remember, this time a year ago, we're a negative. So recognize, this is change over a prior data points important as well. But 3 to 5, I would tell you, my expectations of any reasonable period of time, maybe be not a single data point or quarter, 3 to 5 on bodily injury tells me so that we're in reasonable norm range. So we're not seeing anything on frequency that is shocking or different down or inconsistent with our expectations for the future. And I say expectations for the future because that's what it all comes down to is how you price for June of next year, not necessarily tomorrow. So the one place on frequency that I would say is a bit more of a callout is the clue. Collision is up around 6%. And while it hasn't necessarily been a data point consistent with prior data points, it's not a inconsistent with what we would see is the macro economic forces. We reported and others have reported, I think we can do it in a little bit more quick manner that mileage on a month over month over month basis is up about 4%. So miles driven definitely are up, we measure that through our Snapshot. I have the most recent month, and that seems to be consistent with the annual trend. We have 1 or 2 spikes, Labor Day weekend, those sorts of things. But for the most part, think of mileage being up 4% year-over-year. That's clearly consistent with the trend on gasoline consumption, but again, we've had too many factors to go into there with gas efficiencies and so on and so forth. So we know that, that's a driver. I would say, as you think about the effective frequency you also factor in of course, severity. And we are in a very nice position with severity management, specifically on our bodily injury claims. So ICC has severity there, almost offsetting the frequency. That's a string I don't expect to last forever. We're always trying to improve our claims processes. And you know that they're certainly ones we're very, very proud of, but we found ways that we think we can even improve that. That's been an ongoing initiative inside of claims. So we have a nice offset for now. But frequency will be the to watch. But we are not shocked that it's in that sort of longer-term, normal range or I call it normal range 3 to 5. Collision has both a frequency uptick and a severity up tick. That would be something that while it doesn't cause us headaches from a reserving perspective as much as a bodily injury or UMPD might, that's certainly something that, as you would detect hopefully from my letter, don't get behind on pricing. Make sure that we don't assume that today's prices last forever. And the key for us, and hopefully I tried to give a little color on this, you can take all of these factors, little bit of a change in frequency, definitely some moving parts and severity, try to see what the real norms are, try to project the future and make sure that we take that pricing in increment that doesn't disturb our momentum and doesn't shock our customers and certainly doesn't get us behind the eightball. That's clearly a very complex set of destinations, but that's the real issue for now. And I don't see any signs of either frequency or severity that are unmanageable in the light of being able to also be able to be very nimble and quick and adjusting our pricing. And I'll come back to a statement that we made, because all of this can be summarized with a rather pity phrase we made at our IR meeting that said 3 1s are better than 1 3. And what we meant there was that recognizing all of these changes happen next month's single order points will be different. It's really just matching that trend over time. And the single biggest macro driver, frequency, I would agree with most of the other comments in the industry, mileages there. I noted last time, you also need to be very conscious of mileage and how it's being used. So trips over 15 miles, that is the place we're actually seeing mileage increasing versus the commuting to work more often. That clearly doesn't happen. Does that hit most of your requests?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. In fact, just to follow up on that. So you've hit a good point that severity for Progressive is about minus 1. We've seen for the industry more in the 2% to 5% range. So if you put it all together, frequency, as said, 3% to 5%, that say that
componenttext: Yes, it does. In fact, just to follow up on that. So you've hit a good point that severity for Progressive is about minus 1. We've seen for the industry more in the 2% to 5% range. So if you put it all together, frequency, as said, 3% to 5%, that say that severity caused that to normalized levels. Progressive I believe, is grading rate around 4%. Do you anticipate Progressive having to raise rates more near term? Number one. And number two is would you be able to sacrifice the near-term profitability, and since everybody's hurting? And so would you be willing to let your combined score up near term so that you can Gainshare? And then sort of trace [ph] it back up in 2017?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions in there. First of all, current pricing actually is in very good shape. I'm not going to give you our indications, but probably more than I've ever done before. We'd tell you instantaneously, our indications are not positive. So that's a goo
componenttext: Two questions in there. First of all, current pricing actually is in very good shape. I'm not going to give you our indications, but probably more than I've ever done before. We'd tell you instantaneously, our indications are not positive. So that's a good place to be. The real issue is taking a little bit of rate to stay on the crest of the breaking wave and not go over it. That is the challenge, and that's the challenge I outlined. I don't think, a, I am willing and nor do I think it is necessary for us to sacrifice our #1 commitment to shareholders, and that is a produce an aggregate 96 for our products. For our close observer, you will notice that direct, which is growing very, very well, we'll have at least on an accident year basis, a little bit of pressure on it relative to that 96. It's a complicated message to say we'll never sacrifice the 96. But can I expect that with a higher and very satisfactory inflow of new business, indirect, that I will be more comfortable operating an accident year aggregate for that part of the business, higher than a 96? You bet you. Because we know how that business runs up. We have high confidence. We're not betting on the future. That's a simple bet. And if we can take on the new business where we think that's appropriate, we're going to do that. So don't expect us to be moving in directions of cutting back or our advertising. We think we got been momentum. We're going to keep that momentum. We're just going to keep a little bit of rate coming along so that our rates stay and keep us on the crest of that way. And frankly, these are market conditions that are extraordinary for us. And it's up to us to make sure that we ride them out as best we possibly can.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I could just add to that. This is John. If we allow that calendar or accident year period for direct to drift up to the 97, we're still very confident that business is running out on a lifetime basis at or materially below that 96 combined ratio. And the
componenttext: I could just add to that. This is John. If we allow that calendar or accident year period for direct to drift up to the 97, we're still very confident that business is running out on a lifetime basis at or materially below that 96 combined ratio. And the other business segments we run, we don't necessarily target a 96. So we think it's a different businesses having different target margins, depending upon the marketplace, their appetite. But again, the aggregate we are always very conscientious around running that below the calendar year 96.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ryan Tunis from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ryan Tunis from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question, Glen, I was a little bit surprised to hear you talk about BI frequency in the 3% to 5% range seem normal. Because I think back and Investor Day, you talked about contemplating all longer-term downtick secularly in frequency. So
componenttext: I guess my first question, Glen, I was a little bit surprised to hear you talk about BI frequency in the 3% to 5% range seem normal. Because I think back and Investor Day, you talked about contemplating all longer-term downtick secularly in frequency. So I'm wondering if that's normal for now? Or if there's a change there now you're thinking about frequency longer term?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair to call out and out, Ryan. My career has been based on something that might not be the next 30 years as well, so 3% to 5% is how I've always felt. I think that's how we feel is the norm for now. To the extent that our pressures macro pres
componenttext: Yes, that's fair to call out and out, Ryan. My career has been based on something that might not be the next 30 years as well, so 3% to 5% is how I've always felt. I think that's how we feel is the norm for now. To the extent that our pressures macro pressures in terms of vehicle technology and so on and so forth, but that will change. But the likely influence of that in the [indiscernible] short term is going to be so small that it won't change my 3% to 5% for some time. But do I believe that 30 years from now, we'll be sitting with different measures? Probably.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just add to that. So Glen started out saying we should be looking at a trend series as opposed to a data point. And absolute, if you look at the very long-term trend of, a positive number on frequency and a negative number on severity is not what we expec
componenttext: Just add to that. So Glen started out saying we should be looking at a trend series as opposed to a data point. And absolute, if you look at the very long-term trend of, a positive number on frequency and a negative number on severity is not what we expect. And as we showed you at Investor Day has not been the case for the past 4 decades or so. So important to think of the longer term. Again the most important question is are we priced for tomorrow and for next year? And as Glenn said, we feel pretty confident where we're sitting, and we continue to have robust appetite for growth.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess just shifting gears to a guest again about capital management. Growth this year has been robust, obviously, you've grown at home, which is a little bit of a capital-intensive product as well. And I think in the past, obvi
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I guess just shifting gears to a guest again about capital management. Growth this year has been robust, obviously, you've grown at home, which is a little bit of a capital-intensive product as well. And I think in the past, obviously you've been able to play some capital at year-end via special dividend. I'm just wondering how we should think about balancing out again in growth in capital return heading into the end of the year relative to maybe what you did like 2012 and 2013?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we get this question, actually smiling a little bit, I hope I know it's lame response or if we get our question about this time each year, let's just let the year play out. The special dividend, you had to the means to determine where we stand on
componenttext: I think we get this question, actually smiling a little bit, I hope I know it's lame response or if we get our question about this time each year, let's just let the year play out. The special dividend, you had to the means to determine where we stand on that. So it's not a secret any way shape or form come in many other capital management which sent the same thing so many times that we care a lot about the effect of capital management and good capital husbandry and if we think there something more to do, we'll do it. Are other options, but we've always had said that we want to invest in the business. We've got some nice growth going. We can fund that growth, that's great. But if there are other opportunities, that will be used. And if not, we'll return on deliverance capital a weeping that's the right thing to do. But we just don't make forward-looking statements on that. And frankly, there's enough volatility in the investment marketplaces to just say, let's just -- let's count it on a day that we're supposed to count it.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. And then I just want to sneak one more on agency. I think, Glenn, you highlighted in your letter that renewal -- that the renewal -- or that the retention measures in agencies are still lagging a little bit on the new issued apps. I'm ju
componenttext: That makes sense. And then I just want to sneak one more on agency. I think, Glenn, you highlighted in your letter that renewal -- that the renewal -- or that the retention measures in agencies are still lagging a little bit on the new issued apps. I'm just wondering if you had to take more rate and agency, that would seem to put more pressure on renewals. I mean,, is it reasonable to think that if you had to take more rating in the agency channel, you can still generate some growth there?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is. And I just want to sort of try to measure this. This comes back to the thing statement that I just said, 3 1s better than 1 3. It's a question of how you take rate. We have certainly been on these calls and told you that we are taken rate in l
componenttext: Yes, it is. And I just want to sort of try to measure this. This comes back to the thing statement that I just said, 3 1s better than 1 3. It's a question of how you take rate. We have certainly been on these calls and told you that we are taken rate in larger quantities. That with actually get the right thing to do we need to do it. But it has an equal and opposite offset in affecting consumers and putting consumers into the shopping marketplace. Clearly, there's no perfect number, but we do a lot of work on elasticity of the consumer relative to the size of rate change that they can absorb. And also, you have to sort of factor in the competitive environment. So right now we're seeing a lot of rate actions, greater rate actions than we ever needed to take this year, in all channels, but certainly the agency channel. And as a result, we're competitive in that channel and it's shown by our new apps. Can we sustain a gradual rate increase to match our future expectations of trends? Yes, I think we absolutely can, And shouldn't be assumed that it's quite as dramatic as a binary kind of take rate therefor growth comes up, we're really trying to signal. And my comment, well designed or not, about the paranoia that I have is exactly that. It's how can you just creeping your rate in and win some close observers are Progressive, we actually have some things built in structurally to our rate quarter in many states where we actually have ways of matching continuous inflation or trends. And those are ways to keep all changes relatively low, so we don't shock the consumer. We don't want to do that. But at the same time, keep up with trends. So to answer your question is, how we almost certainly will have to take some rate in all channels over a reasonable period of time. This is not an industry where rates yet are systemically going down. So we'll do that. The real question and the only question I think is on the table for the continued momentum Progressive, can we match that in small increments and stay right with inflation? And we had a perfect opportunity to be able to do that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Shanker of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Shanker of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question about the variable dividend. I saw the note in the 10-Q. I'm just wondering, is that at your discretion? If under writing income were below conference of income, could the -- and the board can do anything, could you choose to pay the dividend a
componenttext: A question about the variable dividend. I saw the note in the 10-Q. I'm just wondering, is that at your discretion? If under writing income were below conference of income, could the -- and the board can do anything, could you choose to pay the dividend anyways?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me answer that a little bit -- I'll answer it. But the board has final discretion. The board also has discretion to do a special dividend. So they have a lot of discretion. So my comment about managing capital, there is clear discretion built in. With
componenttext: Let me answer that a little bit -- I'll answer it. But the board has final discretion. The board also has discretion to do a special dividend. So they have a lot of discretion. So my comment about managing capital, there is clear discretion built in. With regard to the trigger, it'll either a trigger or won't trigger. If we gave you and analysis as of right this moment, it would be different than the analysis at the end of the quarter. So the variable dividend is designed to give to the board a very clear set of understanding. If it triggers, expect it to be paid. If it doesn't trigger, yes, there is some discretion.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can I assume that the circumstances that have led to this condition right now are not the circumstances that this trigger mechanism was designed for in the first place?
componenttext: And can I assume that the circumstances that have led to this condition right now are not the circumstances that this trigger mechanism was designed for in the first place?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that. No. Think about it from a shareholder perspective. We're having a great banner year in terms of operations. I fully respect that. But even if it's on a total mark-to-market basis, if your capital is not doing what you wanted to do
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that. No. Think about it from a shareholder perspective. We're having a great banner year in terms of operations. I fully respect that. But even if it's on a total mark-to-market basis, if your capital is not doing what you wanted to do, then you might question the logic of giving it back at that point in time. And that's what the trigger was designed to at least be in place to do. It worked exactly as designed in 2008, and I admit that was a much more dramatic set of circumstances, where the operating income was positive, but clearly the mark-to-market and our portfolio suggested it would not have been the right move to do. This year, you know the market as well as I do. It's interesting that we were close. And when I say close, I mean close. So we'll just let that 1 play out. So it's in place to do exactly this situation. And relevant to your first question, if you ever had a situation and please do not try to read more into my statement in just what I'm saying, if you ever had a situation that was simply -- that doesn't make sense, then why that's why discretion was put in place as part of the whole dividend structure.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Alison Jacobowitz to with KBW.
componenttext: Next question is from Alison Jacobowitz to with KBW.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: One question on the severity, and I'm kind of thinking of the best way to ask this. Was the moderation in BI severity of function of the frequency increases. But if you look at the same sort of claims, you're seeing the same rates of increasing costs? Or
componenttext: One question on the severity, and I'm kind of thinking of the best way to ask this. Was the moderation in BI severity of function of the frequency increases. But if you look at the same sort of claims, you're seeing the same rates of increasing costs? Or is there something else going on we.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good observation. Certainly, you could say that a higher frequency of smaller claims coming in, and that will clearly change your severity. And that probably has a contravening piece, but I would tell you that the greater contribution has been a
componenttext: That's a good observation. Certainly, you could say that a higher frequency of smaller claims coming in, and that will clearly change your severity. And that probably has a contravening piece, but I would tell you that the greater contribution has been a very orchestrated initiative in that claims organization to take a very close look at specials, managing the specials appropriately. And there are literally hundreds of ways to do that and to do it accurately and correctly, making sure that we have our liability assessments. As we grow, we always have newer people, so it's a never ending job to keep going back and making sure liability determinations and contributory advantages and the like are absolutely taken into account in the right way. So those initiatives are absolutely in place, and we're seeing some very positive results from them. I would tell you our specials to general ratio is going down. These are all active managements. So I would read in most of the change in severity to be active management as opposed to mix-driven.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Clarifications, when we say specials, we mean the medical cost portion of the bilateral entry claim and the generals were the pain and sufferings. So as you know it on the cost portion of it, we think more accurately of the items.
componenttext: Clarifications, when we say specials, we mean the medical cost portion of the bilateral entry claim and the generals were the pain and sufferings. So as you know it on the cost portion of it, we think more accurately of the items.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's helpful. If I could switch gears to Commercial Auto. You noted in the Q something of a mixed shift with writing large policies, and I'm guessing that the competitive situation is getting better there. Is that the reason that you're seeing some
componenttext: And that's helpful. If I could switch gears to Commercial Auto. You noted in the Q something of a mixed shift with writing large policies, and I'm guessing that the competitive situation is getting better there. Is that the reason that you're seeing some year-over-year compression in the underwriting margin in Commercial Auto? Or is that just the anticipated erosion from the nominal possible levels?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Why don't you take that?
componenttext: Why don't you take that?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we are very happy with Commercial Lines margins. So any erosion were seeing is simply migration is -- most immigration, might be a targets. So we are growing a lot in the truck and the Commercial Lines spectrum. We report our new business average premi
componenttext: So we are very happy with Commercial Lines margins. So any erosion were seeing is simply migration is -- most immigration, might be a targets. So we are growing a lot in the truck and the Commercial Lines spectrum. We report our new business average premium to you as well as our renewal, and we are seeing a line of business coming in on the trucking end. We took a lot of rate there, probably 2 years ago now, 2 to 3 years ago, instituted some material changes in our underwriting to tighten up. So we think we got ahead around market. And when we look at our combined ratios across the segments, meaning truck down to what we call business auto, we're very comfortable with what we're seeing in there again, very interested in continuing to grow at a rapid pace. We're seeing great trends there. So any margin erosion you're seeing, we're not at all concerned with, and we are still well below the target combined ratios in all of the segments we write in Commercial Lines.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

componenttext: And just add one more comment, wasn't specific in your question, but maybe it's a good reminder, if you didn't know. We often say we're focused on high-frequency, low-severity claim that adjudicate relatively quickly. Some of the zones of Commercial Auto take you into higher type them at business. Just make a mental note that anything over $1 million is reinsured, so we're not really subject to that sort of very low-frequency, high-severity hit. We've decided to run our business in a way where we're much more comfortable with the underlying limits. And therefore, we don't have quite the same volatility at higher claims.

componenttext: And as you noted in our Q, perhaps a little bit different plays to some comedies that have been reporting recently around reserve development in that segment. Yes, I'm here. Sure. As far as the diversification benefit from a portfolio point of view, we do think about the assets in that part of the business being longer duration, claims a little bit longer tail risk and managed from a more conservative perspective than our order book.
[Audio Gap]

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: We may have lost Bill, maybe I can pick that up. So the Commercial Lines certainly grow and is now getting to a point of sort of 15% of premium outside of the property, which has slightly higher capital requirements for shares we're running higher busines
componenttext: We may have lost Bill, maybe I can pick that up. So the Commercial Lines certainly grow and is now getting to a point of sort of 15% of premium outside of the property, which has slightly higher capital requirements for shares we're running higher business there, but not materially higher than the Personal Auto. The property side is still, while new to us for sure, it's still very small. And we continued to power the approach that ASI had when we took a majority interest in the company, which is to only have a maximum of 10% of surplus at risk in any given store. So you can see from statutory filings, they used reinsurance extensively and protect capital pretty, pretty well. And again, relative to the total Progressive capital, it's pretty small. So there may be some diversification benefit there. We obviously consider the premium-to-surplus ratios. Their growth rate Latorre required by the line of coverage, maybe required is a strong word, but generally looked to. Obviously, the rating agencies as well. So dear's greater capital requirements in property, where we were very comfortable at auto at a 3:1 property. You can think you probably have that, and we consider that into our capital models. And ensure that we continue to have plenty of contingency capital. And to the other question around dividends and capital deployment, we are very much comfortable we call it our balanced range. So we're doing modestly different things in terms of capital management given ASI. But again, it's a pretty small piece of our business now, pretty conservatively managed with reinsurance. So not a big deal at the total balance sheet level.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just go back to the frequency situation, sorry to belabor this, but the 3% to 5%, when you talk about 3% to 5%, is that different from what we would se ISA reporting? Because if I look at long-term frequency trends, they've been actually flat to down for
componenttext: Just go back to the frequency situation, sorry to belabor this, but the 3% to 5%, when you talk about 3% to 5%, is that different from what we would se ISA reporting? Because if I look at long-term frequency trends, they've been actually flat to down for more than a decade. And even if I look at when you're reporting in frequency, since the beginning of '09, it's been flat.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you probably have a better perspective on long term. So clearly, I recognized the 3% to 5%. I'm just saying it's sort of not unrealistic and not sort of unusual. We've also shown you, as John talked about in the IR meetings, the long-term frequency t
componenttext: Yes, you probably have a better perspective on long term. So clearly, I recognized the 3% to 5%. I'm just saying it's sort of not unrealistic and not sort of unusual. We've also shown you, as John talked about in the IR meetings, the long-term frequency trends 30 years. And frankly, we're forecasting the next 30 will not be significantly different, maybe even steeper. Frequency is going down. But at any moment in time, for pricing purposes, especially when you have a macroeconomic change in the economy and miles being driven, 3% to 5% does not sort take me out of the range that I'm uncomfortable with or have seen in general. Maybe Gary, if you can comment on the long-term 12-month [indiscernible]

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Now this is Gary Traicoff, chief actuary. I think of a long-term, Glenn, with a fast-track industry data, and Progressive data, frequency is down. When we look at just particular quarter, so if we take second quarter of this year to second quarter o
componenttext: Sure. Now this is Gary Traicoff, chief actuary. I think of a long-term, Glenn, with a fast-track industry data, and Progressive data, frequency is down. When we look at just particular quarter, so if we take second quarter of this year to second quarter of last year, from fast-track data, it's a little over 2%, and we were about 1.5%. So we're a little bit below that. If I look at fast-track over the last year, they're about 1% as well as Progressive. We don't have third quarter fast-track data yet. But when I'm comparing our data versus industry data, at least over the last 3, 4 quarters, it is up overall by tracking very closely to each other.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then Glenn, going back to the HTC business, your renewal ratios, continuing to be negative here. I'm just curious when do you think that could potentially stabilize a word turn positive we and then also, in that question, the Plat
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then Glenn, going back to the HTC business, your renewal ratios, continuing to be negative here. I'm just curious when do you think that could potentially stabilize a word turn positive we and then also, in that question, the Platinum product, when you think that could potentially have an impact on those retention ratios in your 2 [ph] businesses?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Retention on the direct site is actually behaving predictably and well. And what a try to do and I admit, I'm a little bit in the cautious camp. I hope I'll only stay there that I'd like to see things before I report them happening. And on the agency
componenttext: Yes. Retention on the direct site is actually behaving predictably and well. And what a try to do and I admit, I'm a little bit in the cautious camp. I hope I'll only stay there that I'd like to see things before I report them happening. And on the agency side, it's just -- frankly, it's just a lot slower to sort of show the pick up that I think we should reasonably expect given our market competitiveness and rate competitiveness. But I think it's coming, and I would just say, give me another quarter to confirm that. And I'll confirm it or guide you exactly what's going on. I had thought that we would probably would be able to do a more positive statement about agency retention in the third quarter. When you can't do it, don't do it. With regard to Platinum, recognize Platinum for now is going to be a very small part of the business. So that's going to be hard to see blend into the entire retention trend. That's probably something we'll start to call out for you more deliberately because you just simply won't be able to pull that out of the macro numbers. And that's fine, we'll be happy to sort of give you at least color as to our expectations on Platinum. But we can start with a very clear subject that I have given. Part of the reason why ASI and Progressive are working the way they're working together is that we had no doubt from our first work in PHA that when customers bundle, they have highly retentive behavior. And there is nothing that has adjusted to us that, that is not going to play out in the scenarios that we have in place on the direct side and now on the Platinum side. So Platinum's pretty exciting for us and for the agency. So we look at it as a source of growth for the agency. We look at it as a source of new customer mix. And we certainly look at it as a source of customer mix that will show different retention, behaviors, longer than we have typically experienced. So all positives on that one.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: While Platinum is going to be a fairly small part of our independent agency production here in the near term, we're starting slower there. And absolutely, that bundle is far more likely to stay with us. The precursor of the Platinum program is our newest
componenttext: While Platinum is going to be a fairly small part of our independent agency production here in the near term, we're starting slower there. And absolutely, that bundle is far more likely to stay with us. The precursor of the Platinum program is our newest product model. And we have worked hard to continue to get more and more competitive on preferred business with iterative product miles we're ruling out. And what we're seeing with the latest product model is more mixed to multicar, which inherently retains longer, more mix to its full coverage, towards customers who had their insurance and please for a longer periods. So that's new business mix. That takes a while to move into the book to affect overall retention levels. But while we're seeing our current book getting a little more stable and improving in terms of retention, we're getting new business in that we think will retain longer as well. So we think we've got a number of forces there that will push that retention number into the positive territory soon.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just for those, following along, we often talk about the product as 8.3, the new product going to the marketplace. But we've also talked at our IR meeting about the next one, 8.4. I know they're not glamorous titles, but 8.3 is in about 12 states righ
componenttext: And just for those, following along, we often talk about the product as 8.3, the new product going to the marketplace. But we've also talked at our IR meeting about the next one, 8.4. I know they're not glamorous titles, but 8.3 is in about 12 states right now and is still tightly coupled with Platinum, even though Platinum is in 8 states right now, it was about form for the go. Those are the same states, there's just a slight delayed. And then you've also heard us talk about the new model for Snapshot. That's really all part of 8.3 as well. So the same states will have each of those. And I reported previously both disappointment with uptake in Snapchat by the agency channel and the new product model offering a discount Upfront have actually moved the needle on that. We'd be far away from suggesting it's guiding to the direct levels, it hasn't. But it has gone in the range of double what it was. So a new Snapshot model also leads to what we expect will be longer retention, simply because those who get the right rates are likely to stay in the marketplace and they won't be able to necessarily shop for a better rate than that. Having said all of that, we've also told you that there will be the opportunity for a smaller percentage of the book to get rate increases to some of those people will be more inclined to leave. We'll try over the next year to give a very clear picture of the moving parts that involve in retention, but we would -- sitting here today, we would be disappointed if we didn't see the agency retention start to track on a nice upward path. And that's a good question, if not answer answered in our other documents for the fourth quarter.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

And then when you think about this call again next quarter, what would you have to see from frequency to start to be concerned about the potential threat perception, if you feel the like that's a risk at all?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually your point on adverse selection is not a bad one either. Obviously, Snapshot work is trying to find people live we believe us a group will be lower for currency and bring them into the book, welcome them in at a rate level that is good. And for t
componenttext: Actually your point on adverse selection is not a bad one either. Obviously, Snapshot work is trying to find people live we believe us a group will be lower for currency and bring them into the book, welcome them in at a rate level that is good. And for those that have what we considered to be high frequency likely behaviors, they may not join us as rapidly. So there is some adverse election. We hope it's actually not adverse to us. We will -- it's almost impossible to answer your question specifically. We have to do our indications based on forward-looking estimates of frequency, severity. We've combined them we call a pure premium. And that's going on, on a daily basis, and I mean daily. We will make estimates, and we have estimates. They are probably a little bit tamer than the single data point at the last quarter. And if that data point continues to start to suggest it's a little bit more of a time sequence, we will adjust very quickly for that. The point that I've been trying -- hopefully I have been making is we will take what we see now in small increments. So even if we get higher frequency or higher severity in the future, we can -- we're already on path to have prized that in. We just don't want to get behind the curve on doing that. And if we saw something, it's not a single rate revision. We don't take rates across the country on a single day. We're taking rates all the time. It's a very dynamic structure. We spent a lot of time and money making sure our systems can allow us to take rate changes relatively quickly. And that's the key. If you've got some uncertainty, take a half a point, take a point. We're not ever trying to do that in a sense that the consumer is having to bear the brunt, but it's absolutely in the best long-term interest of the consumer that we can take a point now, maybe a point in 6 months, maybe a point somewhere else. That is a stylized representation of what actually happens at individual states and in individual factors and individual geographies within the state. So it's much more complex than when we talk about it in generalities. But to your more specific question, if we -- even if though really think the long-term frequency trend will be negative. If we see on wrought, certain conditions, mileage so on and so forth that start to push it up a little bit, we will be very active in changing our longer-term estimates. And when mean need longer-term here, I don't mean that the very long term. I mean the life of the price point that will exist in the marketplace. Another advantage that we have is we try to leave those price points in the marketplace as limited a time as possible. So it might be that we change them 3 or 4 times a in a year. And the higher number of times we change them, we're more able to adapt to the estimates that we see as we look to price for that future period. So keeping the trend period as short as possible often works to our advantage.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 06, 2015

componenttext: And through -- you mentioned through the quarter and it into October that frequency trend stabilized, that it wasn't rising. Was it reverting? Can you just briefly touch on that? .
